answers.answer: Hi there.From what you have described, it seems that the problem is vascular. Meaning, this has something to do with the arteries or blood vessels supplying the muscles  of the hips, thigh, and lower extremities.  These problems arise more commonly in patients with predisposing conditions such as obesity, hypertension, and metabolic disorders like diabetes mellitus.  I suggest that you discuss with your doctors regarding exploring this angle, and possibly have tests that will assess the arteries such as magnetic resonance angiogram or conventional angiograms.Take care and God bless.

question: After standing for a short period (only 20 minutes or so) my legs start to go numb and if I don't sit down right away they will get a burning feeling in them and it is very painful.  Before they get the burning feeling in them, they get really cold.  What could be causing this?  I've been to several different docotrs, but haven't found out much about it yet.Thanks for any information you would be able to provide.
title: Tingling and numbness in the legs
